page.title: 08A SIKH TEMPLE IN SOUTHALL
page.content: The{Sikh}temple is called a Gurudwara. There is one situated in Oswald Road. It has a saffron coloured triangular flag flying outside it. There is a sign called the{Khanda} on the flag. The temple is spacious with decoration on the ceiling and the walls. The floor is covered with white sheets on which everybody sits crosslegged. The men sit on one side and the women on the other. At one end of the hall is the{Granth Sahib,}the Sikh holy book, and everybody faces it. You enter the temple barefooted and with the head covered out of respect for the Granth Sahib. Every temple has a communal kitchen called{Guru Ka Langar.} Part of the service is sharing a communal meal. Anyone and everyone who comes has the right to partake in the Langar. There is one other main Gurudwara in Havelock Road.
